title: Sunrise: Matt Doran replaces host of Channel Seven's breakfast show
text:
Channel Seven's breakfast division is set for a shake-up following the cancellation of current affairs show Sunday Night.

Sunday Night reporter Matt Doran will replace Basil Zempilas as co-host of Weekend Sunrise, according to industry website TV Tonight.

Basil, who is based in Perth and commutes to Sydney on weekends, previously said in August that he would be scaling back his role on Weekend Sunrise.

Wake-up call: Channel Seven's breakfast division is set for a shake-up following the cancellation of Sunday Night. Pictured: Sunrise co-hosts Samantha Armytage and David Koch

TV Tonight reports that Basil 'will remain part of the Sunrise family' but his weekly travel schedule was just too 'demanding'.

Meanwhile, Matt will be stepping in as the regular Weekend Sunrise co-host alongside Monique Wright beginning Saturday, October 12.

Basil first joined Weekend Sunrise in March 2018 when he took over from Andrew O'Keefe, who was the show's longest-serving anchor.

News just in! Sunday Night reporter Matt Doran (right) will replace Basil Zempilas (left) as co-host of Weekend Sunrise, according to industry website TV Tonight

Remember him? Basil first joined Weekend Sunrise in March 2018 when he took over from Andrew O'Keefe (right), who was the show's longest-serving anchor

Matt's promotion to breakfast TV comes after Sunday Night was axed by Channel Seven earlier this week.

The announcement was made on Wednesday, with Seven's director of news and public affairs Craig McPherson saying it was a 'very tough decision in a challenging TV landscape.'

'After 11 years at the forefront of our Public Affairs offering, it is with much sadness I announce the closing down of the day-to-day operations of Sunday Night,' he said.

End of an era: Matt's promotion to breakfast TV comes after Sunday Night was axed by Seven earlier this week. Pictured: the Sunday Night team, including host Melissa Doyle (centre)

Mr McPherson confirmed that Sunday Night will remain on air until the end of the year, with a 'small production team' continuing to produce episodes.

As reported by The Daily Telegraph, network bosses told staff members they will be allocated 'new jobs within the network' following the cancellation.

Meanwhile, Channel Seven executives are hoping to replace the show with a 'resurrected' version of Today Tonight.

The cancellation was reportedly part of a 'major overhaul' at the network to reduce costs and eradicate 'duplicate roles'.

authors: Alisha Buaya For Daily Mail Australia
